title.narrative: Resilient Efficient Agribusiness Chains in Uganda (REACH)

description.narrative: The REACH-UGANDA project is an innovative four-year that aims at improving market engagement for 40,000 market-oriented farmers, strengthen household resilience, and deepen availability of agriculture support services for farmers and businesses. The Making Markets Work for the Poor (M4P) methodology has been integrated fully into REACH-UGANDA’s objectives to achieve full engagement with the private sector and sustainably and favourably integrate 40,000 smallholder farmers into commercial supply chains

title.narrative: REACH is seeking to integrate productivity, profitability, and resilience. REACH-Uganda’s integrated approach will provide technical assistance, capacity building, and market facilitation to enhance the productivity of smallholder farmers and FBGs. Moreover, REACH-Uganda will increase the profitability of all actors within the value chain through tighter vertical and horizontal linkages and facilitate resilience approaches to reduce risk in the value chain in the event of market or climate shocks. The integration of market-oriented farmers into the core commodity supply chains will be boosted by facilitation of improved availability and uptake of value chain support services that will further enhance the resilience of the chain actors as well as increase their productivity and efficiency. REACH-Uganda was designed with some very ambitious results. High-priority projected results included the following: • By working with both producers and lead firms that are actively processing and marketing products in the rice and potato value chains, REACH-Uganda would increase the turnover of lead firms and the amount of supply that they procure from FBGs. • FBGs would operate more professionally and effectively, and they would realize greater economic returns, which would flow to their members through improved services and shared 2 value that would be distributed to the membership of the organizations. Women and youth involvement in project activities through FBGs is projected to comprise 55% of the total participants. • We further expect 26,000 farmers to increase their yields to at least 65% of optimal levels and to sell produce through formal linkages between lead firms/small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and FBGs. • At least 50 lead firms/SMEs would be screened for participation and at least 25 of those would be engaged in REACH-Uganda Market Systems activities. Sixteen business cases between lead firms/SMEs and FBGs would be further developed and implemented. • Furthermore, REACH-Uganda would increase resilience among producers with at least 18,000 producers applying three or more resilience practices.
